case_name: State of Bihar v. Gaya Electric Supply Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 175 of 1951 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 175 of 1951. Appeal by Special Leave from the Order

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order and decree dated 30th March 1951 of the High Court of Patna by Ramaswami and Rai JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Order and Decree dated the 30th March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Ramaswami and Rai JJ.

facts.text: High Court order in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 19 of 1951 arising out of order dated 18th December 1950 of Additional Sub-Judge Second at Gaya in Title Suit No. 47 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 19 of 1951 arising out of the Order dated the 18th December, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sub-Judge Second at Gaya in Title Suit No. 47 of 1950.

facts.text: Suit filed by the company on 28th September 1950.

anchor.surface_text: under section 34 of the Indian- Arbitration Act for stay of proceedings in a suit filed by the companypany on 28th September, 1950.

facts.text: Licence for supply of electric energy in Gaya obtained by Khandelwal in 1928 under Indian Electricity Act 1910.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relevant to this enquiry are these. A licence of or the supply of electric energy in the town of Gaya was obtained by one Khandelwal in the year 1928 under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

facts.text: Licence transferred to the company in 1932 with Government sanction.

anchor.surface_text: With the required sanction of the Government the licence was transferred to the companypany in 1932.

facts.text: Licence revoked by Government by notification dated 23rd June 1949 effective from 9th July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated 23rd June, 1949, the licence was revoked by the Government with effect from 9th July, 1949.

facts.text: Company filed suit No. 58 of 1949 against State for declaration that revocation was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the companypany filed a suit against the State for a declaration that the revocation of the licence was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

facts.text: Deed of agreement arrived at between company and State on 28th October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit negotiations started between the companypany and the State for a settlement of the dispute and ultimately on 28th October, 1949, a deed of agreement was arrived at between them.

facts.text: Agreement provided company would withdraw suit No. 58 of 1949 unconditionally on 25th October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the agreement and the companyrespondence referred to therein was substantially as follows - That the companypany would withdraw the suit No. 58 of 1949 unconditionally on 25th October, 1949.

facts.text: Within three days of suit withdrawal, State to pay five lakhs advance to company and company to hand over possession.

anchor.surface_text: That within three days of the withdrawal of ,the suit the State of Bihar would make an advance payment of rupees five lakhs to the companypany, and, simultaneously the companypany would formally hand over the possession of the undertaking to an authorized officer of the Government.

facts.text: Parties to make valuations within three months of taking over undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: That both parties will make their respective valuations within three months of talking over the undertaking

facts.text: Arbitration clause for disputes over payment of balance after valuation, to sole arbitrator high government officer.

anchor.surface_text: That in the case of any difference or dispute between,the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the-sole arbitration of a single arbitrator who should be a high government officer of the provincial government of rank equal to or higher than a Divisional Commissioner

facts.text: Arbitration clause in letter dated 13th October 1949 accepted by company on 17th October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitration clause is companytained in a letter dated 13th October, 1949, and was substantially accepted by the companypany in its letter dated 17th October, 1949.

facts.text: State took over undertaking on 28th October 1949 and paid five lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the agreement the respondent took over the undertaking on 28th October, 1949, and also made a payment of rupees five lakhs to the companypany.

facts.text: Company sent valuation of assets Rs. 22,06,072 on 19th January 1950 to Chief Electrical Engineer Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th January, 1950, the companypany sent a statement of valuation of the assets amounting to RS. 22,06,072, to the Chief Electrical Engineer, Bihar.

facts.text: Chief Electrical Engineer stated company valuation fantastic, rough valuation five lakhs, needs details.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Electrical Engineer characterized the valuation of 22 lakhs by the companypany as fantastic and stated that according to a rough valuation the amount would be approximately five lakhs and that the final valuation would be settled after the companypany -had furnished a detailed history of the plants and machineries.

facts.text: Company declined further details, stated time essence, extended to 15th February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany declined to give any further details and stated that time was of the essence of the. companytract and it would be extended from 28th January, to 15th February, 1950

facts.text: Chief Electrical Engineer intimated valuation Rs. 6,56,221 on 6th April 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On 6th April, 1950, the Chief Electrical Engineer intimated that the valuation amounted to Rs. 6,56,221.

facts.text: State intimated appointment of Mr. M.S. Rao as sole arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: the State Government intimated to the companypany that as difference and dispute had arisen relating to valuation, Mr. M. S. Rao, C.S. -was being appointed as sole arbitrator to decide the dispute.

facts.text: Company instituted Title Suit No. 47 of 1950 on 28th September 1950 after section 80 notice.

anchor.surface_text: On 28th September, 1950, the companypany instituted the suit, the subject-matter the application for stay, after necessary numberice under section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: In plaint, company alleged State failed to value or pay by 15th March 1950, committed breach, company rescinded agreement and forfeited five lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it was alleged ,that as the State Government had failed and neglected to make its valuation or to make payment to the companypany by -the 15th March, 1950, it companymitted a breach of the agreement and by reason of this breach the companypany had rescinded the agreement and had forfeited the sum of five lakhs paid as advance by the State.

facts.text: Company prayed for declaration that undertaking belongs to them, damages, receiver, injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany prayed inter alia for the reliefs of declaration that the, electrical undertaking belonged to them, for damages, for appointment of receiver and for injunction.

facts.text: State filed application under section 34 on 9th October 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th October, 1950, the State Government filed the present appli- cation under section 34, of the Indian Arbitration Act.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed stay application holding suit not in respect of matter agreed to refer.

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the suit was numberin respect of any matter agreed to be referred, and that the companyrt had numberjurisdiction to stay the proceedings. In the result the stay application was dismissed.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court in Misc Appeal No.19/1951.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the State Government appealed to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held dispute in suit arose out of agreement and within arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the dispute in the suit was one which arose out of or was in respect of the agreement and that the question in the suit was directly within the scope of the arbitration clause.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on 22nd May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of this companyrt dated 22nd May, 1951, the companypany was granted special leave under article 136 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Company denied arbitration clause still in existence and suit not connected.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany denied the allegations of mala fides and pleaded that the arbitration clause was numberlonger in existence and that even assuming it to be in existence, the suit was in numberway companynected with the same

facts.text: State claimed arbitration agreement subsisting and suit covered by clause.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated therein that the companypany had with a, dishonest and mala fide motive and with a view to avoid the decision of the matter in dispute in arbitration instituted the suit on incorrect and false allegations. that the arbitration agreement was still subsisting and valid and binding on the parties
By an order of this companyrt dated 22nd May, 1951, the companypany was granted special leave under article 136 1  of the Constitution.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for stay of legal proceedings where matter agreed to be referred to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of, the Indian Arbitration Act runs thus - Where any party to an arbitration companyment Cost any legal proceedings against any other party to the agreement in respect of any matter agreed to be ,referred, any party to such legal proceedings may, apply to the judicial authority before which the proceedings are pending to stay the proceedings, and if satisfied that there is numbersufficient reason why the matter should number be referred in accordance with the arbitration agreement and that the applicant was, at ,the time when the proceedings were companymenced, and still remains, ready and willing to do all things necessary to the proper companyduct of the arbitration, such authority may make an order staying the proceedings.

From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which companyes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement. Where, however, a suit is companymenced as to a matter which lies outside the submission, the companyrt is bound to refuse a stay.

holdings.text: The legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement. Where, however, a suit is commenced as to a matter which lies outside the submission, the court is bound to refuse a stay.

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement. Where,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of section 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act based on its plain language.

holdings.text: The present dispute is about the Government of Bihar committing breach of the agreement by failing to make valuation or pay the balance within time (time being of the essence), leading to rescission of the agreement and forfeiture of the advance; it is not a claim for valuation or payment of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Now as regards the first question, viz., what is the present dispute about, the answer is to be gathered from paragraphs 14 to 17 of the plaint. It is averred therein that the Government of Bihar committed breach of the agreement and failed to make any, valuation of the undertaking or pay the balance of the compensation money, that time being of the essence of the contract

holdings.reasoning_summary: Determination from paragraphs 14-17 of the plaint alleging breach, time essence, rescission, and forfeiture.

holdings.text: The arbitration clause is narrowly worded and covers only any difference or dispute between the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation; it does not cover all disputes arising out of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The clause here is that if any difference. or dispute arises between the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the-sole arbitration of a single arbitrator who should be a high government officer of the provincial government of rank equal to or higher than a Divisional Commissioner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of the clause language and scheme of the agreement requiring government valuation per Electricity Act, with arbitration only for valuation disputes.

holdings.text: Questions relating to the breach of contract or its rescission are outside the reach of this narrow arbitration clause; the arbitrator has not been conferred power to decide if time was of the essence or if the government committed breach by not valuing within time.

anchor.surface_text: Questions relating to the breach of contract or its rescission are outside the reach of this clause. The arbitrator has not been conferred the power by this clause to pronounce on the issue

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow scope of clause limits arbitrator's jurisdiction to valuation disputes only, excluding breach and rescission issues.

holdings.text: The function of the court under section 34 is very limited: it only decides whether the claim comes within the submission to arbitration; it does not go into the validity, merits, or whether the claim is frivolous or vexatious.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one. The only point in such cases

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited jurisdiction under s.34; relies on precedent like Monro v Bognor; High Court erred by deciding merits (no payment stipulation within 3 months).

holdings.text: The dispute in the suit does not fall within the ambit of the arbitration clause; therefore, the proceedings cannot be stayed under section 34.

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.34 scope to facts: dispute on breach/rescission outside narrow clause on valuation payment.

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Simona L. C. in Heyman v. Daruins Ltd 1 . the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a companytract must depend on  a  what is the dispute, and  b  what disputes the arbitration clause companyers. If the arbitration agreement is broad and companyprehensive and embraces any dispute between the parties in respect of the agreement, or in respect of any provision in the agreement, or in respect of anything arising out of it, and one of the parties seeks to avoid the companytract, the dispute is referable to arbitration if the avoidance of the companytract arises out of the terms of the companytract itself. Where, however, the party soaks to avoid the companytract for reasons dehors it, the arbitration clause cannot be resorted to as it goes along with other terms of the companytract.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause depends on what the dispute is and what disputes the clause covers; broad clauses cover disputes arising out of or in respect of the contract, including repudiation if based on contract terms, but not if reasons are dehors the contract
precedents.cited_holding: If the arbitration agreement is broad and comprehensive [...] the dispute is referable to arbitration if the avoidance of the contract arises out of the terms of the contract itself. Where, however, the party seeks to avoid the contract for reasons dehors it, the arbitration clause cannot be resorted to

anchor.surface_text: those companysiderations, as pointed out by Banks J in Monro v. Bognor Urban Council 1 , are material only if the question to be companysidered is whether the case made was a frivolous and vexatious one and ought to have had numberweight at all upon the question of what the plaintiffs claim in fact was and one can only find out what his claim is by looking at the plaint. The learned Judges in the High Court seem to have thought that the arbitration clause here had been drafted broadly and that all disputes arising out of or in respect of the agreements were referable to arbitration.

precedents.cited_proposition: In applications to stay proceedings under arbitration agreements, the court should not consider the merits or whether the claim is frivolous or vexatious; it should only determine if the claim falls within the arbitration clause by looking at the plaint

precedents.citation: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Their reliance on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.   in support of the decision indicates the error. In that case the arbitration clause was drafted in a companyprehensive language and stated that a dispute arising out of the agreement had to be referred to arbitration. Their reference to the case of Governor- General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd. 3  also shows that they were under the same erroneous impression.

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd v Skoda India Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Arbitration clause drafted comprehensively to cover disputes arising out of the agreement

precedents.citation: Governor- General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Their reference to the case of Governor- General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd. 3  also shows that they were under the same erroneous impression. In this case the arbitration clause was in these terms -  1 1915 3 K.B. i67.  2   1937  41 C.W.N. 563. A.I.R. 1948 Cal, 230, Any dispute or difference arising out of the companytract shall be referred to the arbitration of the officer sanctioning the companytract whose decision shall be final and binding. It is obvious that these decisions companyld have numberrelevance to the arbitration clause as drawn up in the present case.

precedents.case_name: Governor-General in Council v Associated Livestock Farm Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Arbitration clause covering any dispute or difference arising out of the contract, to be referred to the officer sanctioning the contract
precedents.cited_holding: Any dispute or difference arising out of the contract shall be referred to the arbitration of the officer sanctioning the contract whose decision shall be final and binding

Precedent supports not considering merits or validity in stay applications, aligning with and supporting the concept limiting s.34 review to arbitration scope excluding frivolousness.

Precedent Monro v. Bognor Urban Council holds that courts should not consider merits in stay applications under arbitration agreements, directly supporting the holding that court function under s.34 is limited to whether claim is within arbitration submission.
